overview: From 2025-10-23 to 2025-10-24, elizaos-plugins/plugin-twitter had 1 new PRs (1 merged), 0 new issues, and 4 active contributors.

topPRs.title: feat: use runtime.handleMessage() for message processing
topPRs.author: 0xbbjoker
topPRs.body:
This PR ensures the Twitter plugin follows the established pattern for message processing used consistently across all ElizaOS platform plugins.

### Current Implementation Status

The Twitter plugin correctly uses the standard messageService API pattern:

```typescript
const result = await this.runtime.messageService!.handleMessage(
  this.runtime, message, callback
);
```

### Context

- `messageService` is a **public property** of the `IAgentRuntime` interface (defined in `packages/core/src/types/runtime.ts:26`)
- This is the **standard API** used consistently across all platform plugins:
  - **Discord**: Uses `runtime.messageService.handleMessage()`
  - **Telegram**: Uses `runtime.messageService!.handleMessage()`
  - **Twitter**: Uses `runtime.messageService!.handleMessage()`

### Changes

- ✅ Verified Twitter plugin uses the correct public API
- ✅ Consistent with Discord and Telegram implementations  
- ✅ Updated `@elizaos/core` dependency to `workspace:*` for local development

### Benefits

- **Consistency**: Follows the same pattern as all other platform plugins
- **Maintainability**: Uses the established public `IMessageService` interface
- **Type Safety**: Proper TypeScript typing through the public interface

topPRs.title: Upload media data is available with Twitter-API-v2
topPRs.author: icecoins
topPRs.body:
Upload media data is available with Twitter-API-v2, please check and update, thanks! 
I have tested this function in my project, it works well with .PNG files.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

## Release Notes

* **New Features**
  * Implemented media upload for tweets. Users can now attach up to 4 media items (images, videos, GIFs) when creating tweets. The system automatically detects media types and formats them appropriately for seamless integration. Media files are now properly processed and attached to tweets during composition.

<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
